body: @dubeejw - Instead of creating another PR for the flag description updates, I just included those changes in this PR.  PG 132

Realized I was using the depricated Python CLI.
The new Go CLI has this capability

Hi @hassenius you can access help by using the flag `-h` or `--help`
It's context aware

Try on any of the two CLIs `wsk action create --help`
It will give you help specific on the create of actions
@jthomas - what do you mean by broken?  Do you mean a deprecated warning is thrown?  The weather tests are passing.
Please reference a pg build when this is ready to be merged.
@rabbah pls let me know when LGTM so I can squash and rebase.

I think we'll have to run a pg on his behalf @jasonpet.
We will need to mirror this against the catalog, yes? In which case, is Travis testing the catalog yet?
@rabbah - sure I can run one, but first we need him to fix up the trailing whitespaces issue.
Yeah, I can update the action over in the openwhisk-catalog to mirror this.  The test for weather however, does not exist in open.  Will only run as part of pg build.
Reviewed - some things to address, kick back to review when ready.

3 suggestions:

1) Move the throttle window `1.minute` to a constant and group it with the 60.   The time window of 1 minute and 60 firings are whisk limit properties and these can be adjusted as needed if we start changing the way we throttle.
2) The parameter maximumInvoke of 120 is really a testing parameter and perhaps shoud be restated as 2*maximumFirings to show that we decide to go at twice the throttle rate to trigger it.
3) Once something is throttled, it would be great if you could stop the Future's that have not been fired from occurring.  One way would be through a condition variable but I leave it to you to do it or not.  It would be good to know how long this test takes on average to complete.  In a perfect world, it would be 1 minute.  When one gets unlucky, it would be 2 minutes if we coded things well.  Since you've gone to the trouble if optimizing, can you indicate what you usually get?

Thanks @perry, i'll have a look at the constants.

To 3: Already did that, check the last commit. It stops as soon as a request is throttled.

The signal approach would mean having to go on the machine and when we scale out the controller, it could be a pain as the admin tasks could become common (monitor-like).  Also, one of the original motivations we discussed:

.5. Reset throttle related parameters that might have gotten stuck for some reason or for which we want to manually override.

New API documented here as a reference:
https://new-console.ng.bluemix.net/docs/services/Weather/weather_rest_apis.html#url_construction

We should add that url in the comments as a quick reference.
Right.  I think we were going to do it but kafka instability (unexplained delays) caused us to put it off.
Do we have an answer on the "waitFor" for kafka without the ping route? I believe we used that to determine in our deployment when kafka is fully up and ready.
I'll do both - no worries. We're accepting that this will make our test outputs more verbose, yes? Is there a PG?
Can we lift the rate limits out of the throttle and parameterize this test accordingly --- If we change the limits upward, will this test catch the lack of throttling?

I will have to create a new bluemix Weather Company Data service and add new entry into vcap file before we will even get a pg build to pass.  The existing Weather Insights service will not work with the updated action.  Once the vcap updates get committed with the new service info I will kick off a pg build.  @jthomas can you please remove the trailing whitespace line in forcast.js for this PR.

Voting to short-circuit early and leave 

`[ERROR] [KafkaProducerConnector] sending message on topic '...' failed: org.apache.kafka.common.errors.RecordTooLargeException: The message is xxx bytes when serialized which is larger than the maximum request size you have configured with the max.request.size configuration.`

an error, because it shouldn't happen once short-circuited?
Thanks for raising this issue Rodric; these decisions we have to document here and in our spec. as we are authoring it.
great idea. as long as we have a shared CLDR, then the UI should be able to pick these up.

PG1-150.

I'd rather accept more log output and disk usage than not knowing what went wrong when I get paged :-)

pg build 136

We talked about relocating this outside the container but were a bit vague about how to do it.  One way we could do it is to post to a dedicated "isAlive" topic and also consume from it as a form of ping.  Presumably, this would be some side script that ansible would have to call.
rebase and merged 4e7cb7e397129cca2cd4920434d35f4231b3e92a

@rabbah @jasonpet @csantanapr There is another issue I have just discovered for WskActionSequenceTests.scala. If all the packages and actions are missing in openwhisk, this test file will fail because system/pipe is unable to find. I tried to create the action and package with the same names, but not under /whisk.system, it still failed to find this action. We have to create this action under /whisk.system to make it work, which means we have to use the auth system key in this case. Do we have another to create the sequence by specifying the actually pipe action instead of system/pipe???

@rabbah @jasonpet @csantanapr @markusthoemmes @dubeejw @mdeuser 
Anyone knows the reason? Thinks we should change?

~~I do believe that action is always there, it's not related to things like a catalog (hence its in the `system` package)~~

~~This is related to #995 where the need of `pipe.js` will go away. @ioana-blue to comment.~~

The CLI shall remove all references to pipe.js. The system does not rely on pipe.js in any system or other package. #995 changes the implementation of sequences and is tangentially related.

@dubeejw @mdeuser see this commit which mage the change for the python CLI (but we missed the go CLI): https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/compare/005a027b6e75...8ff36cd5dbcc
@houshengbo use the python CLI as a temporary workaround.
Use the python CLI as a workaround until #1057 is fixed.

**Memo to self:** Implement tests for:
- [x] Rule activation after deleting the trigger associated should surface a 404 "Only rules with existing triggers can be activated"
- [x] GET on an action/trigger/rule should return a 409 Conflict if the name is tied to an entity of different type
- ~~POST to action/trigger with a payload being too big should result in 413~~ Not "easily" testable with current means (before #1059 is resolved), as you can not pass 1MB to `wsk` (Argument list too long). I'ld postpone this test to #1059.
since many of these tests are the same and only changing the sub commands in a finite and factorable way, you can "generate" them with a loop. See `GoCLINginxTests` for an example (line 86+).
This is a duplicate of #1031 ?

Per discussion with @rabbah, we will maintain 1-11a support until Swift 3 is fully available.   Foundation is not bundled with Swift 2 after this snapshot. We will then make Swift 3 the default.

Can we move these bits from LoadBalancerToKafka to the RateThorttle?

```
                val userCount = activationThrottle.countForNamespace(subject)
                val userLimit = activationThrottle.limitForNamespace(subject)
                info(this, s"(DoS) current activation count for '$subject': $userCount (limit=$userLimit)")
                if (userCount > userLimit) {
                    info(this, s"(DoS) '$subject' maxed concurrent invocations")
                    Future.successful(throttleError)
```
We need to fix this because go cli is otherwise not properly testing sequences.
Fixed test case failure.  PG 161 (lone failure due to cloudant 'create database' failure).

Somehow I missed this discussion and I just got bitten by this issue. I was trying to debug my new code that implements sequences only to realize that my code was not called at all. After some digging, the only sequence test we have uses the go-cli which hardcodes the `pipe.js` hack. It took me some time to understand what was going on since I was still looking at the python cli. For now, locally, I'll make the test use the python cli, but it would be nice if we fix this because the only sequence test we have right now is actually not exercising the code that (currently) implements sequences.
#883 add json validation - unfortunately https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/commit/d5f9ae4277ca3f0ff5f7ca8b8a6815468b9b440e snuck in incorrectly.
PG 163
@starpit can you review change?

I was thinking about this and realized that as a user you could code your action in such a way that you record (somewhere externally) when an action completes. Then compare the actions that were supposed to run and the ones that did run. I think one needs to do this anyway since our model is `run at most once`. @rabbah opened another issue about queuing activations, so I'm closing this one.
looks good.

Hi @andrepoleza for your interest in OpenWhisk.
We have no specific reason why the CLI is not available thru Homebrew.
I think homebrew is a good way of installing dev tools, and it could be a good vehicle to distribute the CLI.

Like anything it would take effort to get it done and also maintain it current (automation CI/CD).

We also need to do some bit of research on how to handle, nightly publish vs. a stable build with the current situation that the CLI doesn't have a semantic version only a hash or build id (i.e. date stamp)

I think after we figured out this we could also potentially offer the CLI thru other package manager (i.e. npm install -g whisk-cli)

I will keep the issue open to keep this a a enhancement request.

@rabbah - Can you provide or point to an overview of the python CLI solution to provide a backdrop for the implementation in the above mentioned commit.  Thanks!
failure's not related to changes: `system.basic.WskBasicNodeTests > NodeJS runtime should Ensure that whisk.invoke() returns a promise FAILED`.

See the commit I linked above from the relevant pull request. The essence of the change:

```
         elif args.sequence:
-            pipeAction = '/whisk.system/system/pipe'
-            exe = self.getActionExec(args, props, pipeAction)
+            exe['kind'] = 'sequence'
+            exe['components'] = self.csvToQualifiedActions(props, args.artifact)
```
@bjustin-ibm - Would you kindly merge this PR for me.  It's ready.  Thanks!

@rabbah As far as I can tell, the code changes seem solid. However, what appears to be missing is documentation describing this new system. Individual action runners have certain obligations and opportunities to customize the way their container runs by implementing one or more of the lifecycle functions defined by the base ActionRunner (e.g. `epilogue`, `verify`, `build`, etc.). However, I don't see any documentation describing these aspects.

I think it would be valuable to have either comments in `actionproxy.py` describing the lifecycle and customization points or, perhaps better, a separate document describing how to create a new action container.

Registrator is nice because it watches containers going down and up. What would happen in a dynamic environment where services come and go? (e.g., invokers leaving and new ones being spawned). It's up to you, my sense is that at one point when we deal with automatic scaling, we'll need something similar. I think this is early optimization.
Travis failure was determined to be an intermittent Cloudant issue. Merged as c8a7f00ac25e3ac378e6678dd864555ee67dcb1f.

I think we'll always know when we deploy what. It's not like containers are going to be around uncontrollably.

It's not really pressing, but i wanted to open a discussion against it.

Good to know! I've never thought about the semantic version and its impact on availability on Homebrew. I just think that distributing the CLI through a broader package manager would benefit OpenWhisk in several ways, because although npm and pip are stable/popular not every (potential) developer uses them.

Anyway, I'll be happy when OpenWhisk reaches Homebrew. 😃
